Award.AwardTitle: Programmable Catalysts Designed to Replicate Flexible Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nature employs catalytic processes to replicate biopolymers (e.g., DNA) from templates. Such processes are vital for sustaining life. Meanwhile, man-made polymers are widely used in everyday life. Learning how to amplify man-made polymers efficiently has important impacts on future advances in many fields, such as medicine, electronics, and renewable energy. With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Prof. Severin Schneebeli at the University of Vermont is investigating how to replicate well-defined, man-made polymers efficiently. His research group aims to develop synthetic approaches to preparing functional polymers from templates in a sustainable manner. Students at all academic levels participating in this fundamental research gain valuable, multi-disciplinary insight and experience in chemical synthesis, computer modeling, and materials science. Furthermore, Professor Schneebeli organizes educational outreach events at the ECHO lake aquarium and science center in Burlington, VT, to engage the public in science.

To reach the aforementioned goals, this research aims to develop catalysts - large molecular strips built with chirality-assisted synthesis - which facilitate the accurate replication of man-made polymers. As steric protection groups, these catalysts are designed to embrace the polymer strands during the duplication processes to reduce common replication mistakes. The synthetic approach focuses on key physical interactions commanding the accuracy of replication for different catalyst/monomer pairs. Ultimately, this research is devised to discover general design rules for the creation of shape-defined, complex macromolecular structures, which can readily be amplified exponentially. Professor Schneebeli unites art, engineering, and chemistry to engage the public in science and its potential outcomes by organizing educational outreach events at the ECHO lake aquarium and science center in Burlington, VT. With interactive, 3D-printed, LEGO-like models, these outreach activities educate the public about the genetic code of life and illustrate how man-made approaches towards sustainable, replication-based materials synthesis relate to nature?s methods of creating materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most important outcome of this project is the development of a new approach to unfold and catalytically functionalize polymer chains with nanoscale catalysts (i.e. hydrazone-linked tetrahedral nanocages). The ability to selectively unfold and at the same time catalytically functionalize polymer chains provides the basis for using nanoscale catalysts to replicate man-made polymer chains, akin to how nature is able to replicate DNA with the help of DNA polymerase enzymes. We not only advanced processes for replicating polymer chains, but also new synthetic methodology for creating large supramolecular catalytic units (including tetrahedral nanocages and spring-like, helical polymers) designed as catalysts to unfold, functionalize, and replicate synthetic polymers. Overall, catalysts able to derivatize man-made polymers for desirable polymer size, sequence, and folded topology are in critical need to make future advances in fields such as medicine, electronics, and renewable energy. Our work now provides one of the first examples for selective catalysis with polymeric substrates as we showed that stable synthetic catalysts with large openings can distinguish between polymer chains of various lengths in a complex mixture, providing proof of principle for selective catalytic polymer functionalization. This concept will be applied to prepare otherwise inaccessible polymers in the future. In collaboration with the Li research group (University of Vermont, Burlington, VT), we were also able to computationally predict the experimentally observed unfolding of the polymer chains induced by our supramolecular catalysts with molecular dynamics simulations.

To create these supramolecular catalysts, we invented a unique enantioselective electrophilic aromatic nitration methodology. Electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions are profoundly important for the synthesis of biologically-active compounds and other advanced materials. They represent an important means to activate specific aromatic C–H bonds without requiring transition metal catalysts. Yet, only very few stereoselective variants are known for electrophilic aromatic substitutions, which limits the utility of these classical reactions for stereoselective synthesis. While many electrophilic aromatic substitutions lead to achiral products (due to the planar nature of aromatic rings), there are important examples where chiral products are produced, including desymmetrization reactions of aromatic cyclophanes and of prochiral substrates with multiple aromatic rings. To provide a solution, we reported a chiral auxiliary, which can convert classical electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions into powerful enantioselective transformations.

A new way to drive thermodynamically unfavored reactions with crystal packing was also discovered, providing access to otherwise very difficult to access molecular building blocks, which are shape persistent and make up the corners of our nanocages used to unfold the polymers for replication. The developed crystal packing amplification technique should be applicable to a broad range of molecular building blocks needed to build shape- and sequence-defined polymeric materials. No solvent is needed for our crystal-packing-driven amplification process, which renders it a green (i.e. environmentally friendly) reaction.

This project provided opportunities for multidisciplinary research to four graduate students, and four undergraduate students.  They were trained in supramolecular chemistry, organic synthesis, polymer chemistry, and computational chemistry.  These students gave poster presentations at national and international meetings and participated in preparation of research papers and reports.  They also performed joint research with our collaborators at the University of Vermont.  Four students obtained their PhDs degrees. Three undergraduate researchers defended Honors theses and moved on to Yale University, Northwestern University, and Boston University for graduate school in Chemistry. The PI and his research group also performed four outreach events (each one with multiple shows, drawing hundreds of visitors) to engage the general public in supramolecular chemistry and polymer chemistry research at the ECHO Leahy Lake Aquarium and Science Center in Burlington, VT. The outreach events featured fun chemical demonstrations for the families in the audience, captivating scientific posters, as well as demonstrations of how real molecules react with virtual reality goggles. The use of virtual reality for teaching organic laboratory courses more effectively was also explored in collaboration with the Li research group, paving the way for more effective, future virtual reality use in chemical education.
